overview_of_class:
Here's an inductive inference: "Whenever I've eaten pizza I've gotten heartburn. Therefore, pizza will give me heartburn." David Hume gave an argument that no argument like this can be rationally compelling: it depends on the thought "the future will be like the past". This thought isn't obvious from reflection, and to argue for it from induction would be circular.

This class is about this problem, and philosophical and mathematical attempts to solve, sidestep, or illuminate it.
name: Scientific Reasoning
title: WCAS PHIL 151-0-20 Scientific Reasoning
